headline: Canada election 2025 results in charts
context: Phil Leake, Alison Benjamin, Daniel Wainwright and Jess Carr

annotations.paragraph: BBC
annotations.reason: Source credit line without informational content

annotations.paragraph: Mark Carney's Liberal Party has won enough seats in the House of Commons to form a government in Canada.
annotations.reason: Reports the core election outcome for the winning party

annotations.paragraph: However, CBC News projects they will fall short of the majority they wanted.
annotations.reason: Provides important detail about the result lacking a majority

annotations.paragraph: Carney is set to remain prime minister, having only assumed the role in early March following Justin Trudeau's resignation.
annotations.reason: Offers relevant background on the new PM and continuity

annotations.paragraph: His main rival, Conservative leader Pierre Poilievre, has lost his own seat as has Jagmeet Singh, leader of the New Democratic Party (NDP).
annotations.reason: Highlights major upsets for party leaders, central to election narrative

annotations.paragraph: Carney's Liberals have 168 seats but would need 172 for a majority.
annotations.reason: Specifies the seat count and threshold for majority, key election detail

annotations.paragraph: The Conservatives are set to remain in opposition as the second-largest party and are on 144 seats, with over 99% of polls having reported results.
annotations.reason: Gives crucial information about the main opposition party's result

annotations.paragraph: The Bloc Québécois is on 23 seats and only runs candidates in the province of Quebec. The NDP has been reduced to seven seats and the Green Party to one.
annotations.reason: Details seat distribution for smaller parties, relevant to overall outcome

annotations.paragraph: Both the Liberals and the Conservatives have seen a significant rise in their share of the national vote compared with four years ago.
annotations.reason: Notes voting share trends, contextualizing results over time

annotations.paragraph: Increased support for Canada's two largest parties has come at the expense of smaller parties, particularly the NDP whose share of the popular vote is down by almost 12 percentage points.
annotations.reason: Explains shifts in voter support, important analytical context

annotations.paragraph: The rise in support for the Conservatives was not enough to save Poilievre, who lost his own seat in Carleton, Ontario.
annotations.reason: Links vote share to a significant outcome for a party leader

annotations.paragraph: The 45-year-old had promised a return to "common sense politics".
annotations.reason: Vague campaign slogan without direct relevance to election outcome

annotations.paragraph: Opinion polls at the start of the year had the Conservatives over 20 percentage points ahead of the Liberals. But after the resignation of former Liberal Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and the arrival of new PM Mark Carney and the tariffs announced by US President Donald Trump, that lead evaporated.
annotations.reason: Provides essential background on poll swings impacting election dynamics

annotations.paragraph: In his own seat, Poilievre had 90 opponents, mostly independent candidates linked to a group calling for electoral reform.
annotations.reason: Gives significant detail on the level of competition in a key race

annotations.paragraph: NDP leader Singh also lost his own seat in the House of Commons, coming third behind the Liberal and Conservative candidates.
annotations.reason: Reports a crucial result for another major party leader

annotations.paragraph: Canada has a first-past-the-post" electoral system.
annotations.reason: Explains electoral mechanics relevant to interpreting seat outcomes

annotations.paragraph: The candidate who gets the most votes in each electoral district, or riding, wins that seat and become a Member of Parliament (MP).
annotations.reason: Further clarifies the voting system for reader understanding

annotations.paragraph: The Liberals and the Conservatives have dominated the popular vote, with both parties receiving more than 40% each of ballots counted across Canada.
annotations.reason: Details popular vote percentages, pivotal election data

annotations.paragraph: This has them on track to win a combined 90% of seats.
annotations.reason: Interprets vote share into seat projection, key analytical insight

annotations.paragraph: The NDP has received just over 6% of the total vote, but this translates to just 2% of seats in the House of Commons.
annotations.reason: Highlights disproportionality in vote-to-seat conversion, relevant analysis

annotations.paragraph: The Bloc Québécois has just over 6% of the vote and a similar share of seats.
annotations.reason: Compares vote share to seat count for a regional party

annotations.paragraph: The Liberals have the most seats in the key provinces of Ontario and Quebec, which account for 200 of Canada's 343 electoral districts.
annotations.reason: Identifies provincial breakdown critical to overall results

annotations.paragraph: The Conservatives took all but three of the 37 seats in Alberta, while it was a close race between the two main parties in British Columbia, where the Conservatives have 19 seats and the Liberals 20.
annotations.reason: Provides detailed provincial seat outcomes, relevant to regional analysis

annotations.paragraph: One of the most closely-watched areas was around Toronto. The "905" are places that all share the same telephone code.
annotations.reason: Introduces a focal region for election coverage

annotations.paragraph: While the Liberals have won in most of Toronto, including a seat they lost in a by-election last year, the Conservatives were able to flip some of the ridings in the surrounding region.
annotations.reason: Reports key swings in a pivotal urban region

annotations.paragraph: The NDP have lost a seat, Hamilton Centre, that they'd held for over 20 years.
annotations.reason: Highlights a significant historical upset for a party

annotations.paragraph: After Ontario, Quebec is the second most populated province of Canada and has a big impact on the results of federal elections.
annotations.reason: Contextualizes Quebec's importance in federal results

annotations.paragraph: The Bloc Québécois, which focuses on Quebec interests and only runs candidates in the province, was defending 35 seats, a number which changed after boundaries were reviewed. It has lost 12 of them, according to preliminary results.
annotations.reason: Details seat changes for a major regional party

annotations.paragraph: The Liberals won back LaSalle-Émard-Verdun, which the Bloc took in a by-election last year.
annotations.reason: Notes a specific seat gain relevant ato party fortunes

annotations.paragraph: The NDP held on to their seat in Rosemont-La Petite-Patrie in Montreal.
annotations.reason: Reports a retained seat for a party leader's party

annotations.paragraph: Turnout has surpassed the levels seen in 2015 and 2019, with 69% of registered electors having voted. This is according to the preliminary results from Elections Canada.
annotations.reason: Provides voter turnout data, essential election metric

annotations.paragraph: More than 7 million Canadians cast their ballots in advance, setting a new record for early voter turnout, Elections Canada said.
annotations.reason: Highlights record-breaking early voting figures
